questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of balance issues, headache, and nausea for the past 4 days. The patient endorses a sensation of objects moving around him. The patient was diagnosed with infective endocarditis one week ago and has been receiving penicillin G and gentamicin. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, heart failure, and hypertension. Other medications include furosemide, metformin, atorvastatin, aspirin, and metoprolol. Vitals are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination is normal. Air conduction is better than bone conduction with Renne testing, and sound is heard better in the left ear with Weber testing. Rapid movement of the head away from a fixed target induces a horizontal eye saccade with redirection towards the target. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient receiving gentamicin for the treatment of infective endocarditis presents with new-onset hearing loss, imbalance, and sensations of objects moving around him (oscillopsia). This presentation is consistent with aminoglycoside-induced ototoxicity likely exacerbated by coadministration with furosemide (another ototoxic drug). Other risk factors for aminoglycoside-induced ototoxicity include bacteremia, as well as hepatic, or renal impairment.

Irreversible vestibular and auditory dysfunction can follow aminoglycoside administration. Presentation varies and includes clinical features such as:

  •  High-pitched tinnitus (usually the first symptom of cochlear toxicity)  
  •  Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and loss of high-frequency range (outside the conversational range)  
  •  Imbalance and oscillopsia   
  •  A positive head thrust test (impaired vestibulo-ocular reflex)  

Management of aminoglycoside-induced vestibular toxicity includes immediate discontinuation of the offending medication. Associated renal toxicity is typically reversible and presents in the form of acute tubular necrosis (ATN). It is common in elderly patients receiving aminoglycosides as well as in those concurrently receiving amphotericin B, cephalosporins, or vancomycin.

Option Analysis

❌ Meniere disease :
Incorrect: Meniere disease is caused by increased endolymphatic volume/pressure in the labyrinthine system. It presents with a triad of episodic vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss. Acute onset of vestibular dysfunction, rather than episodic dysfunction, makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
✅ Medication-induced ototoxicity :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cholesteatoma :
Incorrect: Cholesteatomas are erosive expansile masses of squamous cell debris in the middle ear visible on the otoscopy. This condition typically presents with recurrent otorrhea and asymmetric conductive hearing loss (bone conduction> air conduction in the affected ear). 
❌ Otosclerosis :
Incorrect: Otosclerosis results from ossification of the ossicles and presents with conductive hearing loss (bone conduction> air conduction) rather than sensorineural hearing loss. 
❌ Presbycusis :
Incorrect: Presbycusis is common in the elderly (age > 75 years) and presents with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of severe left ear pain and discharge. The symptoms started three days ago and have progressively worsened. The pain is worse during the night time. The patient also reports discomfort and pain while chewing from the left side of the jaw. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus, as the patient is noncompliant with medication and follow-up visits. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg. Physical examination reproduced severe pain on moving or touching the pinna. Otoscopic examination shows granulation tissue in the inferior portion of the external auditory canal at the bone-cartilage junction. Initial cultures show a motile, oxidase-positive, Gram-negative rod. Which of the following antibiotics have activity against the organism responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has severe ear pain, discharge, and granulation tissue in the ear canal. This, in combination with uncontrolled diabetes and initial culture findings (motile, oxidase-positive, Gram-negative rod), is consistent with malignant otitis externa, secondary to infection by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This patient should be treated with systemic piperacillin, an extended-spectrum penicillin.  

Extended-spectrum penicillins, also known as antipseudomonal penicillins (e.g., piperacillin, ticarcillin) have activity against several Gram-negative rods, including Pseudomonas, Enterobacter, and in some cases Klebsiella species. Most drugs in this subgroup have synergistic actions with aminoglycosides against such organisms. Piperacillin and ticarcillin are susceptible to penicillinases and are nearly exclusively used in combination with penicillinase inhibitors (e.g., tazobactam, clavulanic acid) to enhance their activity.

Option Analysis

❌ Nafcillin:
Incorrect: Nafcillin is a penicillinase-resistant penicillin that is effective against Staphylococcus aureus (except MRSA). It has no activity against Gram-negative rods.
✅ Piperacillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cephalexin:
Incorrect: Cephalexin is a first-generation cephalosporin and is effective against Gram-positive cocci, Proteus mirabilis, E. coli, and Klebsiella pneumoniae and can be used for surgical prophylaxis and treatment of urinary tract infections and minor skin and soft tissue infections. It is, however, not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: Doxycycline is a tetracycline that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is usually used in the management of Borrelia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia, or Chlamydia infections. It is, however, not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
❌ Chloramphenicol:
Incorrect: Chloramphenicol is a bacterial protein synthesis inhibitor, effective in the management of meningitis and/or rickettsial diseases. It is, however, not effective in the management of malignant otitis externa caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of nasal congestion. His parent reports the patient has had nasal congestion and an evening cough for two weeks. The patient’s three-year-old brother had similar symptoms that have since resolved. The patient was improving, but four days ago, he developed worsening nasal discharge and fever to 39.2°C (102.6°F). His parent has not noticed a change in appetite. The patient has not had a sore throat, ear pain, or headache. He is otherwise healthy. Current temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 96/71 mm Hg. The physical exam is notable for edematous and erythematous nasal turbinates, and purulent mucus is visualized in the posterior nasopharynx. The pediatrician suspects acute bacterial sinusitis. This infection most likely spread to which of the following anatomic spaces?
questions.solution:
The nasal cavity has numerous connections to its surrounding spaces. It is important to remember the relationship between the nasal cavity and its surrounding structures because nasal congestion can cause inflammation and swelling of the mucosa close to the openings of these spaces. When the surrounding spaces are unable to drain properly, infection can develop and spread.

In particular, the maxillary sinuses are the most common site to which an infection in the nasal cavity might spread. The openings (or ostia) to the maxillary sinuses are small and can be easily obstructed when the surrounding nasal mucosa becomes congested. Also, because of the orientation of the maxillary sinuses in the skull, it is difficult for them to drain properly when the head is upright or lying on one side; the ostia are directed towards one another, so when lying on the side, only the top sinus can actually drain.  



Option Analysis

❌ Frontal sinus  :
Incorrect: The frontal sinus is located in the frontal bone and opens into the anterior part of the middle meatus via the frontonasal duct. While it is possible for an infection to reach the frontal sinuses, the maxillary sinuses are a more common site of spread from a nasal cavity infection.  
❌ Anterior ethmoidal cells:
Incorrect: Anterior ethmoidal cells drain directly or indirectly into the middle nasal meatus through the ethmoidal infundibulum. The anterior ethmoidal cells are not a common site of spread from a nasal cavity infection.  
❌ Middle ethmoidal cells  :
Incorrect: The middle ethmoidal cells open directly into the middle meatus and are called “bullar cells”  because they form the ethmoidal bulla–a swelling over the superior border of the semilunar hiatus. The middle ethmoidal cells are not a common site of spread from a nasal cavity infection.  
❌ Sphenoidal sinus  :
Incorrect: The sphenoid sinus lies inferior to the sella turcica and communicates with the nasal cavity via the sphenoethmoidal recess. It is an uncommon site of sinus infection.
✅ Maxillary sinus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the office of his maxillofacial surgeon for follow-up after having dental implant surgery on the lower molars. The patient has inadvertently bitten his inner cheek several times since the surgery due to reduced sensation around the gingiva. The patient also endorses persistent pain in the lower molars, gingiva, chin, and lower lip. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diminished sensation over the lower teeth and chin. Oral examination shows well-appearing dental implants with superficial lacerations over the bilateral inner cheeks. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured given this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Incisive branch of the nasopalatine nerve

questions.solution:
The inferior alveolar nerve courses into the mandibular canal and provides sensation to the roots of the lower teeth. This nerve exits the skull through the mental foramen as the mental nerve and provides sensation to the lower lip and the skin of the chin. Before entering the mandible, the inferior alveolar nerve gives off a motor branch to the mylohyoid muscle, innervating the mylohyoid and anterior belly of the digastric muscles.

Because of its close relation to the teeth, the inferior alveolar nerve is the most commonly injured nerve during oral surgery. It can be injured during third molar extraction, dental implant surgery, or tumor removal. Injury symptoms include paresthesias, complete numbness, or pain in the teeth, gingiva, chin, and lower lip.  



Option Analysis

❌ Buccal nerve  :
Incorrect: The buccal nerve courses into the cheek and pierces the buccinator muscle. This nerve carries sensation from the skin over the cheek and the inner mucous membrane. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.  
❌ Lingual Nerve  :
Incorrect: The lingual nerve courses into the tongue and carries sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.  
✅ Inferior alveolar nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incisive branch of the nasopalatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The incisive branch of the nasopalatine nerve carries sensory information from the front of the hard palate, just behind the incisors. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.  
❌ Lesser palatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser palatine nerve carries sensation from the soft palate. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being assaulted at a local bar. He sustained facial trauma, including multiple lacerations and multiple punches to the face. He reports right-sided jaw pain and teeth malalignment. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 120/64 mmHg. CT of the facial bones demonstrates a right-sided displaced mandibular fracture. The patient is subsequently taken to the operating room for operative repair by otolaryngology. The anesthetist injects a local anesthetic agent between the coronoid notch and the pterygomandibular raphe of the right mandible. Injection of an anesthetic into this space is likely to anesthetize which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
An inferior alveolar nerve block is the most common anesthetic procedure performed in dental surgery.  The most critical clinical landmarks used to locate the inferior alveolar nerve include the coronoid notch and the pterygomandibular raphe–the preferred needle insertion site lies between these two landmarks. Successful injection anesthetizes all mandibular teeth to the median plane, the skin and mucous membrane of the lower lip, the labial alveolar mucosa and gingiva, and the skin of the chin.


Other nerves anesthetized during dental procedures are summarized in the table below:  


Option Analysis

❌ Greater palatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The greater palatine nerve is best anesthetized by injecting an anesthetic into the greater palatine foramen. This nerve block anesthetizes the palatal mucosa and lingual gingiva posterior to the maxillary canine teeth and underlying palate. This nerve emerges between the 2nd and the 3rd molars.  
❌ Lesser palatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser palatine nerves pass through the lesser palatine foramina posterior to the greater palatine foramen. This nerve supplies sensation to the soft palate, tonsils, and uvula.  
❌ Nasopalatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The nasopalatine nerve can be anesthetized via anesthetic injection into the incisive fossa. Affected tissues include the palatal mucosa, the lingual gingiva and alveolar bone of the six anterior maxillary teeth, and the hard palate.  
✅ Inferior alveolar nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anterior superior alveolar nerve  :
Incorrect: The anterior superior alveolar nerve (or anterior superior dental nerve) is a branch of the infraorbital nerve that innervates the anterior teeth and joins the middle superior alveolar nerve to form the superior dental plexus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to an urgent care clinic for evaluation of an ongoing nose bleed. He has been pinching his nose for approximately three hours, but the bleeding has persisted. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, and he has no known history of trauma or bleeding disorders. Upon arrival, temperature is 98.0°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 168/85 mmHg, pulse is 75/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination shows significant bleeding from both nostrils and draining to the back of the throat. Which of the following anatomical locations is the most likely etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of hypertension and a presentation with ongoing epistaxis that has failed to stop despite applying pressure. He most likely has posterior epistaxis.  

Epistaxis can be divided into two categories: anterior epistaxis and posterior epistaxis. Anterior epistaxis makes up the majority of cases and usually causes mild to moderate bleeding. It originates from a region of the anterior nasal septum called the Kiesselbach plexus, formed via the anastomoses of the anterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and superior labial artery. Anterior epistaxis can usually be managed by pinching the nasal alae together for at least 10 minutes while sitting upright. Vasoconstrictors (e.g. phenylephrine) and electrocautery may be needed in rare cases.  

Posterior epistaxis makes up around 10% of cases, typically presents in elderly patients and those with a history of hypertension, and manifests with more severe bleeding. It arises from bleeding from the Woodruff plexus, a vascular network formed by anastomoses between the sphenopalatine and posterior pharyngeal arteries. Treatment may involve electrocautery, nasal balloons, and posterior nasal packing. Sometimes, the internal maxillary artery and its branches must be ligated to control the bleeding.

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior ethmoidal artery:
Incorrect: The anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery. It gives off nasal branches that supply the lateral wall and septum of the nose. It contributes to the Kiesselbach plexus and is therefore responsible for anterior epistaxis. However, this patient has a history of persistent nasal bleeding over several hours, more consistent with posterior epistaxis.  
❌ Superior labial artery:
Incorrect: The superior labial artery is a branch of the facial artery. It gives off septal branches that supply the nasal septum and ala of the nose. It contributes to the Kiesselbach plexus and is therefore responsible for anterior epistaxis. However, this patient has a history of persistent nasal bleeding over several hours, more consistent with posterior epistaxis.  
❌ Maxillary artery:
Incorrect: The maxillary artery supplies the deep structures of the face. A terminal branch of the maxillary artery is the sphenopalatine artery, which supplies the Woodruff plexus. Bleeding from the Woodruff plexus can result in posterior epistaxis. However, the maxillary artery itself is not directly involved in posterior epistaxis. 
❌ Kiesselbach plexus:
Incorrect: The Kiesselbach plexus is a vascular network of four arteries that supply the nasal septum. Approximately 90% of nosebleeds occur in the Kiesselbach plexus. The Kiesselbach plexus is responsible for anterior epistaxis. In contrast, this patient has a history of persistent nasal bleeding over several hours, more consistent with posterior epistaxis.  
✅ Sphenopalatine artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric emergency department for evaluation of an intractable nosebleed after being hit in the face with a basketball during recess. He does not have any shortness of breath, hemoptysis, or hematemesis. There is no family history of bleeding disorders. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/64 mm Hg. The physical exam is notable for clots in the nares, with moderate rebleeding when the clots are dislodged. Which of the following anatomic locations is the most likely site of ongoing bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with uncomplicated epistaxis (nosebleed) following facial trauma. The most common source of bleeding in patients with uncomplicated epistaxis is the Kiesselbach plexus–an area found in the anterior third of the nose. Anastomosis of the following blood vessels occurs in this region:  
  •  Septal branch of the anterior ethmoidal artery 
  •  Lateral nasal branch of the sphenopalatine artery 
  •  Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of the facial artery) 

Posterior epistaxis, on the other hand, occurs from bleeding in the Woodruff plexus–a collection of arteries in the posteroinferior nasal cavity formed by the anastomoses of the sphenopalatine artery (branch of the maxillary artery) and pharyngeal artery. Posterior epistaxis often presents as difficult to control bleeding from the bilateral nostrils or hemoptysis. Posterior epistaxis is highly associated with brisk bleeding into the posterior pharynx and thus a higher risk of airway compromise or aspiration.




Option Analysis

❌ Inferior turbinate  :
Incorrect: The inferior turbinates, along with superior and middle turbinates, are involved in warming, filtering, and humidifying inspired air. They are unlikely sites of epistaxis.  
❌ Posterolateral wall  :
Incorrect: Branches of the sphenopalatine artery supply the posterolateral wall and are the most likely source of posterior nosebleeds. Epistaxis secondary to injury of the sphenopalatine artery or its branches results in brisk hemorrhage that is difficult to control with direct pressure or specific interventions.  
✅ Kiesselbach plexus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior choanae  :
Incorrect: Branches of the sphenopalatine artery supply the posterior choanae and are the most likely the site of posterior nosebleeds. Epistaxis secondary to injury of the sphenopalatine artery or its branches results in brisk hemorrhage that is difficult to control with direct pressure or specific interventions.  
❌ Middle meatus  :
Incorrect: The middle turbinate over the lateral nasal wall forms the middle meatus, a drainage pathway for the frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinus. It is the most common site for nasal polyps to form but is unlikely to be involved in anterior nasal bleeds.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is evaluated on inpatient rounds for a retropharyngeal abscess. Temperature is 102 °F, pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient is awake and oriented and appears tired. He is not struggling to breathe and is otherwise resting comfortably. An area of erythematous inflammation is seen in the posterior oropharynx, and the patient has mild submandibular lymphadenopathy. Parenteral antibiotic therapy is initiated with clindamycin and metronidazole. The physician explains to the parents at the bedside that urgent treatment is required due to the potential spread of infection into a region called the “danger space.” Which of the following best describes the boundaries of this space?

choices.text: Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly
Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly
Pretracheal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly
Alar fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly

questions.solution:
Posterior to the pharynx, there is a potential space called the retropharyngeal space. This space is bounded anteriorly by the buccopharyngeal fascia, the superior continuation of the pretracheal fascia, and posteriorly by the alar fascia. Infection in the retropharyngeal space can also lead to a retropharyngeal abscess, resulting in difficulty swallowing and speaking.

Another important space is the ‘danger space,’ which is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral layer of the deep cervical fascia. This space extends from the base of the skull into the posterior mediastinum and down to the level of the diaphragm, making it the most important route for the spread of infection between the neck and thorax.



Option Analysis

❌ Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly:
Incorrect: These are the boundaries of the retropharyngeal space. The ‘danger space’ is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia.  
❌ Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly:
Incorrect: The ‘danger space’ is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia.  
❌ Pretracheal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly:
Incorrect: The ‘danger space’ is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia.  
✅ Alar fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to an urgent care facility due to ongoing epistaxis. The patient endorses experiencing facial trauma while playing basketball. His parent states that she has been applying pressure and pinching his nose for the past 30 minutes. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient’s temperature is 97.7°F (36.5°C), blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals moderate volumes of blood and multiple clots from the nostrils. Which of the following blood vessels is most likely involved in this patient’s bleeding?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with epistaxis from the nostrils after experiencing facial trauma. He most likely has anterior epistaxis.   

Epistaxis can be divided into two categories: anterior epistaxis and posterior epistaxis. Anterior epistaxis makes up the majority of cases and usually causes mild to moderate bleeding. It originates from a region of the anterior nasal septum called the Kiesselbach plexus, formed via the anastomoses of the anterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and superior labial artery. Anterior epistaxis can usually be managed by pinching the nasal alae together for at least 10 minutes while sitting upright. Vasoconstrictors (e.g. phenylephrine) and electrocautery may be needed in rare cases.    

Posterior epistaxis makes up around 10% of cases, typically presents in elderly patients and those with a history of hypertension, and manifests with more severe bleeding. It arises from bleeding from the Woodruff plexus, a vascular network formed by anastomoses between the sphenopalatine and posterior pharyngeal arteries. Treatment may involve electrocautery, nasal balloons, and posterior nasal packing. Sometimes, the internal maxillary artery and its branches must be ligated to control the bleeding. 

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior pharyngeal artery:
Incorrect: The posterior pharyngeal artery is a branch of the external carotid artery. It anastomoses with the sphenopalatine artery to form the Woodruff plexus, which is involved in posterior epistaxis. This patient more likely has anterior epistaxis. 
❌ Woodruff plexus:
Incorrect: The Woodruff plexus is a vascular network formed by the anastomosis of the sphenopalatine artery and posterior pharyngeal artery. It is responsible for the posterior epistaxis. However, this patient’s young age and relatively mild bleeding from the nostrils are more consistent with anterior epistaxis. 
❌ Ophthalmic artery:
Incorrect: The ophthalmic artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery. It gives rise to the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries. While downstream branches of the ophthalmic artery (e.g. anterior ethmoid artery) contribute to epistaxis, the ophthalmic artery itself plays no direct role in the condition.  
✅ Kiesselbach plexus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Internal carotid artery:
Incorrect: The internal carotid artery is a branch of the common carotid artery. While some smaller downstream arteries contribute to epistaxis, the internal carotid artery itself plays no direct role in developing this patient’s condition.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of jaw pain. The pain started two hours ago after yawning, and now he cannot open or close his mouth. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness over the bilateral periauricular areas with palpable indentation of the preauricular space. The patient’s mouth is open and fixed. The coronoid process of the mandible is prominent and palpable just below the maxilla. Persistent spasm of which of the following muscles contributes to this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an anterior temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dislocation. TMJ dislocations occur when the mandibular condyle travels anteriorly and becomes locked at the superior anterior aspect of the articular eminence of the temporal bone, preventing closure of the mouth. Anterior TMJ dislocations are associated with stretching of the ligaments surrounding the TMJ and severe spasms of the muscles that open and close the mouth (i.e., the masseter, medial and lateral pterygoid, and temporalis muscles).

Anterior dislocations are the most common type of TMJ dislocation and often result from atraumatic mechanisms that involve excessive translational movement of the mandible. Examples include excessive yawning, singing, recurrent vomiting, intubation, or dental procedures. Anterior dislocations often present with jaw pain and decreased range of mandible motion (e.g. mandibular depression or elevation). Posterior dislocations are uncommon, as posterior translation is significantly resisted by the presence of the postglenoid tubercle and the strong intrinsic lateral ligament.  



Option Analysis

❌ Buccinator  :
Incorrect: The buccinator compresses the cheek inwards and pulls the corner of the mouth laterally, which aids in swallowing, mastication, blowing, and sucking. The buccinator contributes to mandibular protrusion and retrusion but not depression.  
❌ Genioglossus  :
Incorrect:  The genioglossus is responsible for tongue protrusion rather than the movement of the mandible.  
✅ Lateral pterygoid  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Omohyoid:
Incorrect: The omohyoid travels from the hyoid bone to the clavicle and helps depress the hyoid during speech or swallowing. It is not involved in the movement of the mandible.  
❌ Zygomaticus major:
Incorrect: The zygomaticus major pulls the angle of the mouth laterally and superiorly to facilitate smiling. It is not involved in the movement of the mandible.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to her maxillofacial surgeon for follow-up after having her lower third molars removed one week ago. The patient states since the surgery, she has had limited sensation over her lower teeth and accidentally bit the inside of her cheek. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diminished sensation over the lower teeth and chin. Oral examination demonstrates normal healing of the extraction sites. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
The inferior alveolar nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve, provides sensation to the lower teeth and terminates as the mental nerve. This nerve is at high risk of injury during molar extractions (particularly third molars or “wisdom teeth”) as it travels through the mandible. Damage to this nerve results in sensory deficits and mental nerve distribution.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inferior alveolar nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Superior alveolar nerve:
Incorrect: The superior alveolar nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve, provides sensory information to the maxillary teeth, gums, and sinus. This patient has a sensory deficit along the mandible, not the maxilla.  
❌ Infraorbital nerve:
Incorrect: Damage to the infraorbital nerve manifests with sensory deficits over the lower eyelid, side of the nose, moveable part of the nasal septum, anterior cheek, or upper lip.  
❌ Mental nerve:
Incorrect: The mental nerve is the terminal branch of the inferior alveolar nerve and provides sensory information to the chin and lower lip. This patient’s presentation is consistent with the entire inferior alveolar nerve damage.  
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information over the cheek and temple. This nerve is unlikely to be damaged based on this patient’s recent surgery.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is currently undergoing an adenotonsillectomy secondary to sleep-disordered breathing and recurrent tonsillitis. Intraoperatively, brisk bleeding is noted from the lateral pharyngeal wall after removing the right palatine tonsil. Attempts at cauterization and hemostasis are unsuccessful with continued pulsatile bleeding. The patient’s current vital signs are temperature is 37 C° (98.6 F°), respirations are 18/minute, pulse is 116/minute, and blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
Removal of the tonsils is a common procedure performed secondary to recurrent tonsillitis or sleep-disordered breathing. When the palatine tonsils alone are removed, the procedure is referred to as a tonsillectomy; when both the palatine tonsils and the pharyngeal tonsils (adenoids) are removed, it is referred to as an adenotonsillectomy. Typically, some surrounding connective tissue is also removed during these procedures.

During this procedure, several structures are at risk of injury, including the internal carotid artery, glossopharyngeal nerve, and tonsillar artery. The internal carotid artery lies posterior-lateral to the palatine tonsils and is a source of brisk and difficult to control bleeding when injured intraoperatively. The superior constrictor muscle lies lateral to the palatine tonsil and immediately deep to these muscles. Damage to this nerve can result in referred otalgia and temporary or rarely permanent alteration in taste.  

Option Analysis

✅ Internal carotid artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thyroid ima artery:
Incorrect: The thyroid ima artery is an unpaired, variable branch of the brachiocephalic artery that supplies the thyroid and the isthmus. It is more commonly injured during procedures involving the anterior neck due to its more inferior position in the neck.  
❌ External carotid artery:
Incorrect: The external carotid artery branches from the common carotid artery at the fourth or fifth cervical vertebrae level. This structure is not at risk of injury during a tonsillectomy or adenotonsillectomy.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: The common carotid artery is not at risk of injury during this procedure, given its inferior location in the neck relative to the pharyngeal and palatine tonsils.  
❌ Internal jugular vein:
Incorrect: The Internal jugular vein is a potential source of injury during this procedure; however, it lies lateral to the internal carotid artery. Moreover, this patient presents with evidence of brisk bleeding consistent with an arterial source.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man presents to his ear, nose, and throat surgeon for follow-up after having a parotidectomy due to an invasive mucoepidermoid tumor. The patient reports feeling well, but he has noticed intermittent redness and pain over the area of surgery. In addition, the patient says the site “sweats profusely” every time he becomes hungry or is preparing to eat. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for the finding demonstrated below. Damage to which of the following nerves is most likely implicated in this patient’s disease process?
 

Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic features of Frey syndrome, a rare neurologic disorder that most commonly occurs following parotid gland surgery. This disease is due to damage and improper regeneration of the auriculotemporal nerve--a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3).

The auriculotemporal nerve contains secretomotor, somatosensory, and vasomotor fibers. The superior component of the nerve provides sensation to the tragus and helix of the ear, the external portion of the tympanic membrane, the posterior temporomandibular joint, and the temple. The inferior component provides autonomic parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland.

During parotid gland surgery, the auriculotemporal nerve can become damaged with subsequent aberrant reinnervation of postganglionic parasympathetic neurons of denervated sweat glands and cutaneous blood vessels. When this occurs, flushing and sweating can occur in response to mastication and salivation, resulting in Frey syndrome. Pain, numbness, or anesthesia may also occur in the distribution of the auriculotemporal nerve.  

Option Analysis

✅ Auriculotemporal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information over the cheek and temple. This nerve is unlikely to be damaged based on this patient’s recent surgery.  
❌ Superior alveolar nerve:
Incorrect: The superior alveolar nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve, provides sensory information to the maxillary teeth, gums, and sinus. This patient does not have evidence of a sensory deficit.  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. This patient does not have evidence of facial motor deficits.  
❌ Frontal nerve:
Incorrect: Diminished sensation over the left forehead and scalp may occur with injury to the frontal nerve or its branches. This is likely to occur with a supraorbital rim fracture.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision, stabilized, and admitted for further evaluation and pain control. His initial physical examination demonstrated diffuse contusions and multiple lacerations of the face. Throughout his hospital stay, the patient refuses advanced imaging and is discharged home after two days. Subsequently, the patient returns to the emergency department five days later with continuous rhinorrhea. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates clear rhinorrhea from the right nostril as well as anosmia of the right nostril with the left nostril occluded. Sensation of smell via the left nostril is intact. This patient’s presentation results from injury to which of the following cranial structures?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with loss of smell (anosmia) and clear rhinorrhea following head trauma suggestive of cerebrospinal fluid leak and olfactory nerve injury, secondary to the fracture of the cribriform plate.   

The olfactory nerve transmits olfactory impulses from the olfactory epithelium of the nose to the brain. The central processes of the olfactory nerve make up the numerous nerves which pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. In severe head injuries, the olfactory bulbs may be torn away from the olfactory nerves. Olfactory nerve fibers may be torn as they pass through a fractured cribriform plate. If the nerve bundles on one side sever, a complete loss of smell will occur on that side; consequently, anosmia may be a clue to a fracture of the cranial base and cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea (leakage of the fluid through the nose).  

Option Analysis

❌ Skull base:
Incorrect: Basilar skull fractures can damage CN VIII within the internal acoustic meatus, leading to symptoms of sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, and horizontal nystagmus.  
✅ Cribriform plate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Superior orbital fissure :
Incorrect: The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) passes through the superior orbital fissure. Fractures at this location result in an abducens nerve palsy and loss of lateral gaze on the left.   
❌ Jugular foramen:
Incorrect: The jugular foramen is the site of exit for cranial nerves IX, X, and XI; however, these nerves are involved in swallowing, visceral organ function, and trapezius elevation rather than smell.  
❌ Inferior orbital rim:
Incorrect: Fracture of the inferior orbital rim or maxillary fracture can result in the injury to the maxillary nerve (cranial nerve V2), which normally carries the sensory innervation of the left cheek.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a foreign body sensation in the throat. The patient reports she was eating fish soup when she felt a small bone “get stuck in my throat.” After topical lidocaine is applied to the posterior pharynx, a fishbone is retrieved from the piriform recess under video-assisted laryngoscopy. At her follow-up visit several days later, the patient reports she has noticed a slight change in the quality of her voice. Which of the following anatomical structures was most likely injured during removal of the foreign body?
questions.solution:
The piriform recess (or sinus) is a subsite of the hypopharynx. It is a recess on either side of the laryngeal inlet, bounded laterally by the thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane and medially by the aryepiglottic folds.  It is a common area for foreign bodies to become lodged during swallowing.

The superior laryngeal and its branches lie deep to the mucosa of the piriform recess and may be damaged during lodging or retrieval of foreign bodies from this space. Superior laryngeal nerve damage often manifests with vocal fatigue and subtle changes in voice quality in timbre, pitch, voice projection, and decreased sensation to the laryngeal mucosa.

Damage to the internal laryngeal nerve may result in altered sensation to the laryngeal mucosa, as this nerve only carries sensory information. In contrast, damage to the external laryngeal nerve manifests with changes in voice quality, as this nerve carries motor fibers to the cricothyroid muscle.  

Option Analysis

✅ Superior laryngeal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), when damaged, often presents with new-onset hoarseness, changes in vocal pitch, and noisy breathing.  
❌ Thyroid ima artery:
Incorrect: The thyroid ima artery is an unpaired, variable branch of the brachiocephalic artery that supplies the thyroid and the isthmus. When injured during head and neck procedures, it can be a source of brisk and difficult to control bleeding.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: Injury to the common carotid artery results in hematoma formation and possible neurologic deficits secondary to ischemic or thromboembolic events.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis to both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve. This can result in both sensory and motor deficits of the larynx.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician with nasal congestion, fever, and throat pain complaints. His parent reports the patient had an upper respiratory tract infection last week, which seemed to improve, but his symptoms worsened over the past three days. The patient's current vital signs are temperature is 38.9 C° (102 F°), respirations are 16/minute,  pulse is 90/minute, and blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates purulent rhinorrhea. A flexible nasal endoscope is inserted, which confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following correctly describes the anatomic structure implicated in this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
The tonsils consist of a group of lymphatic tissues in the posterior pharynx/oropharynx and include pharyngeal, palatine, tubal, and lingual. When the pharyngeal tonsils, or adenoids, become inflamed, the condition is called adenoiditis.

The pharyngeal tonsils typically regress by early puberty; therefore, the majority of patients that present with adenoiditis are prepubescent. A typical history includes a child with a recent viral upper respiratory infection that progresses to fevers, purulent rhinorrhea, nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and halitosis. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, and direct visualization of the inflamed pharyngeal tonsils can be achieved via a laryngeal mirror or nasal endoscope.

Commonly implicated pathogens include those responsible for other upper respiratory tract infections, including Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, and Staphylococcus aureus. In addition, environmental allergens and caustic irritation secondary to gastric reflux are known to precipitate adenoiditis.

Option Analysis

✅ Pharyngeal tonsils:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Palatine tonsils:
Incorrect: The palatine tonsils are tonsils located on the left and right sides at the back of the throat, which can often be seen as flesh-colored, pinkish lumps. The palatine tonsils are not the lymphatic tissue associated with acute adenoiditis.  
❌ Thyroid gland:
Incorrect: The thyroid gland lies inferior and anterior to the pharyngeal tonsils--at the level below the cricoid cartilage. The thyroid gland may become enlarged and inflamed for various reasons; however, it is not implicated in cases of acute adenoiditis.  
❌ Tubal tonsils:
Incorrect: The tubal tonsil is located posterior to the Eustachian tube's opening on the nasopharynx's lateral wall. This tonsil may become implicated in cases of eustachian tube dysfunction.  
❌ Parotid gland:
Incorrect: The parotid gland serves as the largest salivary gland and lies on the lateral aspects of the face. The parotid glands cannot be visualized with nasal endoscopy.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to her physician due to a painless lump on the right side of her face. She noticed the mass growing over the past several months, and one week ago noticed a right-sided facial droop. She has no significant past medical history and does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a right-sided, non-tender, mobile, preauricular mass extending  to the angle of the mandible. A right-sided facial droop is present on examination. A biopsy of the mass is performed, and pathological examination shows proliferation of ductal myoepithelial and epithelial cells with a marked increase in stromal components. Staining with S100 is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pleomorphic adenomas are benign tumors consisting of ductal epithelial and myoepithelial cells. The presence of both epithelial and mesenchymal differentiation defines this tumor as “pleomorphic.” Pleomorphic adenomas predominantly affect the parotid gland, although other salivary glands (e.g. submandibular) can be implicated.  

Pleomorphic adenomas typically present as slow-growing, mobile, painless masses. Symptoms and signs depend on the size, location, and potential to undergo malignant transformation. In the parotid gland, symptoms of facial nerve weakness can occur when the tumor is large or undergoes malignant change invading adjacent structures.  

The diagnosis of pleomorphic adenomas depends on biopsy and subsequent pathological examination. It is characterized by mixed proliferation of epithelial and myoepithelial cells in a variable stroma matrix of myxoid or cartilaginous origin.

Option Analysis

✅ Pleomorphic adenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Warthin tumor:
Incorrect: Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum (Warthin tumors) are benign cystic tumors with germinal centers, typically found in patients with a significant smoking history. This patient’s biopsy shows epithelial and mesenchymal differentiation, characteristic of another salivary gland tumor.
❌ Mucoepidermoid carcinoma:
Incorrect: Mucoepidermoid carcinomas have variable amounts of squamous cells, mucus-secreting cells, and intermediate cells. They are the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary glands and occur mainly in the parotid glands. This patient’s biopsy shows epithelial and mesenchymal differentiation, characteristic of another salivary gland tumor.
❌ Sialadenosis:
Incorrect: Sialadenosis typically presents as bilateral, non-tender swelling of the parotid glands; the condition occurs in several systemic conditions (e.g., nutritional disorders, hypothyroidism, cirrhosis). Pathological examination typically reveals atrophy of parenchymal tissue and a compensatory increase in adipose tissue. 
❌ Facial nerve schwannoma:
Incorrect: Facial nerve schwannomas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that commonly present with facial paresis or hearing loss. Schwannomas demonstrate S100 expression; therefore, this patient’s pathological and immunohistochemical staining suggest a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic with a cough over the past week. He recently moved for college. Since beginning school, the patient has noticed a worsening runny nose with congestion, sneezing, and tearing over the past few days. He initially thought it was due to dust from moving into the dorm, but the symptoms have not improved with time. He does not have any pets. Physical examination shows edematous nasal mucosa. Bronchial breath sounds at the lung bases are heard on auscultation. Examination of the eyes reveals the findings shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with cough, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion in the setting of new environmental exposures (e.g. moving to a new city for college). He most likely has allergic rhinitis.   

Allergic rhinitis is characterized by paroxysms of sneezing, rhinorrhea, and nasal obstruction, often accompanied by itching of the eyes, nose, and palate. It is typically caused by hay, dust, pollen, animal dander, or mold spores. A high yield concept is that allergic rhinitis is a type 1 hypersensitivity mediated by immunoglobulin E antibody production and mast cell degranulation. This reaction leads to excess fluid build-up in the nasopharynx.    

On physical examination, one may see prominent creases below the inferior eyelid, referred to as Dennie-Morgan lines (see the image in the vignette). Additionally, the nasal mucosa can appear pale and boggy.    

The diagnosis is usually made clinically. However, diagnostic tests such as patch testing, in which allergens are applied to small patches and stuck onto the skin, can be performed. If the skin under a particular patch becomes irritated, it suggests an allergy to the substance. Blood tests may show elevated IgE and eosinophil levels.    

The best treatment option is to avoid the triggering allergen. However, allergic rhinitis is a persistent condition requiring ongoing therapy in most patients. Glucocorticoid nasal sprays are the most effective single-agent maintenance therapy for allergic rhinitis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Viral conjunctivitis :
Incorrect: Viral conjunctivitis often presents with erythematous eyes with copious tearing. This patient has no evidence of conjunctival injection.  
❌ Moderate asthma:
Incorrect: Moderate asthma can present with dyspnea, chest tightness, and persistent cough. Patients may also have increased respiratory rate, tachycardia, and wheezing audible throughout exhalation. 
✅ Allergic rhinitis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aspirin-induced respiratory disease  :
Incorrect: Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) is characterized by a triad of nasal polyps, asthma, and aspirin sensitivity. This combination of symptoms is known as the Samter triad. This patient does not have any of the three components of this triad. 
❌ Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:
Incorrect: Nasopharyngeal angiofibromas are benign but locally aggressive tumors of the nasal mucosa composed of large blood vessels and fibrous tissues. They often present with profuse epistaxis, unilateral complaints of nasal obstruction, and trouble breathing. While they are most commonly seen in adolescent males, this patient’s presentation and physical exam do not correlate with a nasopharynx angiofibroma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the office with a two-month history of hoarseness and sore throat. He initially came to the office approximately two months ago with similar symptoms and was treated empirically for an upper respiratory infection. Since then, he has developed night sweats and experienced a 2 kg (4.4 lb) weight loss. He has not experienced heartburn, hearing loss, epistaxis, or nasal congestion. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and consumes 3 alcoholic beverages daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the left tonsil is enlarged, with an area of ulceration present on the mucosa. Overproduction of which of the following proteins is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has hoarseness, sore throat, night sweats, and weight loss in the setting of an ulcer on the oral mucosa. These factors, combined with a significant tobacco and alcohol use history, raise concern for oropharyngeal carcinoma.    

Oropharyngeal carcinoma is usually located on the soft palate, palatine tonsillar fossa and pillars, lateral and posterior pharyngeal wall, or tongue base. The leading causes of oropharyngeal carcinoma are chronic tobacco use, alcohol use, and human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. HPV produces the proteins E6 and E7, which inhibit the tumor suppressor proteins p53 and Rb, respectively.  

Patients with oropharyngeal carcinoma are initially asymptomatic, and cervical lymphadenopathy is an early sign. As the tumor enlarges, it can cause persistent sore throat, dysphagia, and mucosal ulceration. In addition, patients can develop constitutional symptoms such as night sweats and weight loss.



Option Analysis

✅ E6 oncoprotein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CD21:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms and physical exam findings consistent with oropharyngeal carcinoma. CD21, also known as Epstein Barr virus receptor, is a receptor that EBV can bind with to infect B-cells. While EBV infection may contribute to the development of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, it does not play a role in the development of oropharyngeal carcinoma. 
❌ p53:
Incorrect: p53 is a tumor suppressor protein that regulates cell cycle and growth. Overproduction of p53 would protect against the development of oropharyngeal cancer. 
❌ CD4:
Incorrect: CD4 is a glycoprotein found on the surface of specific immune cells. HIV-1 uses CD4 to gain entry into host T-cells. However, overproduction of CD4 plays no role in the pathogenesis of oropharyngeal cancer. 
❌ Rb tumor suppressor:
Incorrect: Rb is a tumor suppressor protein that regulates the cell cycle and growth. Overproduction of Rb would protect against the development of oropharyngeal cancer.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to chronic diarrhea and recurrent pneumonia. The patient has had several episodes of pneumonia and bronchitis since he was eight months of age. He currently has a fever and cough productive of thick purulent sputum. The patient’s family immigrated to the United States several months ago. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 38.6°C (101°F), pulse is 91/min, blood pressure is 105/63 mmHg, and respirations are 28/min. Physical examination reveals an ill-appearing boy whose height and weight are at the 8th percentile for his age. Scattered rhonchi over both lung fields are heard on auscultation. A chest x-ray is ordered, and the results are shown below. Which of the following findings is also associated with this patient’s condition?  



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This boy has a fever and productive cough in the setting of chronic diarrhea, recurrent pneumonia, and imaging findings consistent with bronchiectasis. The gastrointestinal symptoms are likely secondary to pancreatic insufficiency. Given these findings, the patient most likely has cystic fibrosis.    

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is the most common genetically inherited recessive disease in the Caucasian population. The many manifestations of this illness are caused by a defective cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene. This mutation results in an absent or mutated CFTR protein. Patients with cystic fibrosis typically have thickened mucus secretions in the lungs and pancreas, leading to chronic cough, frequent lung infections, difficulty digesting food, pancreatic insufficiency, and increased risk of developing diabetes.  

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a condition with symptoms similar to cystic fibrosis. It is caused by a mutation in dynein, a ciliary motor protein. Both conditions can present with nasal polyps, recurrent respiratory infections, and infertility. However, PCD would not typically cause pancreatic insufficiency. Additionally, patients with PCD may also present with dextrocardia.

Option Analysis

❌ Immotile sperm:
Incorrect: Males with cystic fibrosis and primary ciliary dyskinesia do typically present with infertility. This patient, who has cystic fibrosis, would have normal sperm but an obliterated vas deferens. In contrast, in primary ciliary dyskinesia, there is a normal vas deferens, but the sperm are immotile. 
❌ Situs inversus:
Incorrect: Situs inversus is a congenital condition in which the major organs are mirrored or reversed from their normal position. Situs inversus is associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia but not cystic fibrosis.  
✅ Nasal polyps:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Normal mucous secretions:
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis is an inherited disease due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene. The mutation results in impaired chloride secretion, increased water reabsorption from mucosal surfaces, and the formation of hyperviscous mucus.  
❌ Elevated nasal nitric oxide:
Incorrect: This patient has findings consistent with cystic fibrosis. Decreased nasal nitric oxide levels are found in patients with cystic fibrosis and primary ciliary dyskinesia.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for an annual well-visit. He has no complaints and feels well. His past medical history is significant for diabetes and asthma, for which he takes metformin and inhaled corticosteroids and albuterol as needed. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past forty-five years. Vitals are within normal limits. Oral examination reveals poor dentition with multiple cavities and dark-stained teeth. A thin, white patch with well-defined margins is noted on the left upper palate, as seen in the image below. The physician attempts to scrape it off with a tongue depressor but cannot do so. Which of the following factors is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Ebstein Barr virus infection of squamous epithelium

questions.solution:
Oral leukoplakia is a premalignant lesion that presents as a white patch on the oral mucosa. Risk factors for developing oral leukoplakia are similar to those predisposing to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), including alcohol and tobacco use (smoked and especially smokeless).    

Oral leukoplakia most commonly presents as a uniformly thin, white patch with well-defined margins. The growth can be irregular, flat, nodular, or exophytic in other cases. It is important to note that oral leukoplakia cannot be scraped off, unlike oral thrush. Oral leukoplakia is a premalignant lesion, and biopsy is necessary to determine the extent of dysplasia.    

After exposure to a carcinogen, hyperplasia is the first cellular change, and persistent exposure results in atrophy, or cellular degeneration. Following chronic exposure, irreversible cell damage takes hold, manifesting as either apoptosis or malignant transformation. Thus oral leukoplakia can histologically present at any of these stages of cellular change: hyperkeratosis, mild dysplasia, moderate dysplasia, severe dysplasia, or carcinoma in-situ. 

Option Analysis

✅ History of cigarette smoking:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhaled corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Inhaled corticosteroids are a risk factor for oropharyngeal candidiasis (thrush). Although this patient uses inhaled steroids to treat his asthma, oral thrush can be easily scraped off with a tongue depressor.
❌ Inhaled albuterol:
Incorrect: Inhaled albuterol is not a risk factor for the development of leukoplakia. 
❌  Ebstein Barr virus infection of squamous epithelium :
Incorrect: Oral hairy leukoplakia is an Epstein Barr virus-mediated mucocutaneous condition in which the virus most commonly infects the squamous epithelium of the tongue. Hairy leukoplakia presents as a white lesion on the lateral margin of the tongue with “feathery” projections. 
❌ Poor oral hygiene:
Incorrect: Poor oral hygiene can be a risk factor for developing various oral conditions, including oral thrush and leukoplakia. However, cigarette smoking is a more significant risk factor for the development of leukoplakia.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a painless, enlarging mass on the right side of his face over the past several months. He has no significant past medical history and does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a right-sided, non-tender, mobile, preauricular mass extending to the angle of the mandible. The remainder of the physical examination is noncontributory. A biopsy of the mass is scheduled. Pathological examination demonstrates the proliferation of ductal myoepithelial and epithelial cells with a marked increase in stromal components. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to be observed if this patient’s condition remains untreated?

choices.text: Inability to close the right eye

questions.solution:
Pleomorphic adenomas are benign tumors consisting of ductal epithelial and myoepithelial cells. The presence of both epithelial and mesenchymal differentiation defines this tumor as “pleomorphic.” Pleomorphic adenomas predominantly affect the parotid gland, although other salivary glands (e.g. submandibular) can be implicated.  

Pleomorphic adenomas typically present as slow-growing, mobile, painless masses. Symptoms and signs depend on the size, location, and potential to undergo malignant transformation. The facial nerve (CN VII) originates in the brainstem and travels through the temporal bone before exiting the stylomastoid foramen. The subsequent branches of the facial nerve emanate from the body of the parotid gland and divide before innervating the muscles controlling facial expression. Therefore, symptoms of facial nerve weakness can occur if the parotid tumor grows or if it undergoes malignant change. With advancing disease, this nerve impingement may result in findings of ipsilateral eyebrow drooping, inability to close the eye, the disappearance of the nasolabial fold, and drooping at the affected corner of the mouth. 

Option Analysis

✅ Inability to close the right eye:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right-sided facial sensation loss:
Incorrect: Facial sensation (ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular divisions) are mediated by the trigeminal nerve (CN V). This patient’s mass is more likely to cause another neurological deficit. 
❌ Right-sided ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis:
Incorrect: Horner syndrome is a condition characterized by ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and facial anhidrosis (loss of sweating) due to a disruption in sympathetic innervation. This syndrome occurs more commonly in the setting of a lung tumor involving the apex (Pancoast tumor). 
❌ Right-sided sensorineural hearing loss:
Incorrect: Although pleomorphic adenoma most commonly occurs in the salivary glands, it can arise in other parts of the head and neck; a rare location of pleomorphic adenomas is the ear canal. Conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural hearing loss, would occur if present in this location. 
❌ Loss of the gag reflex:
Incorrect: The afferent limb of the gag reflex is mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), whereas the efferent limb is carried by the vagus nerve (CN X). While this patient’s salivary gland tumor (pleomorphic adenoma) can grow and impinge the facial nerve (CN VII), resulting in facial nerve palsy, the gag reflex would remain unaffected.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of unpleasant taste progressing to moderate loss of taste in the past week. She was treated with oral cephalexin for a urinary tract infection several weeks ago and finished her course of treatment before the onset of symptoms. She has no significant past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows white plaques on the buccal mucosa, palate, and tongue. The physician can scrape several plaques using a tongue depressor that reveals underlying erythema with light bleeding. The scrapings are prepared for pathological examination. Which of the following is most likely to be observed on microscopy?

choices.text: Budding yeasts with and without hyphae
Hyperkeratosis overlying a thickened, acanthotic mucosal epithelium
Dysplasia with inflammation and vascular dilation
Lymphocytic infiltrate along the dermo-epidermal junction

questions.solution:
This patient, who recently completed a course of oral antibiotic therapy, presents with white, scrapable plaques on her oral mucosa suggestive of oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush). Candidiasis is an opportunistic infection caused by the fungus Candida albicans that most commonly occurs in immunosuppressed hosts (e.g. AIDS, hematologic malignancies). However, this condition can occur in healthy patients who wear dentures, patients with xerostomia (dry mouth), and those treated with antibiotics or inhaled corticosteroids.    

Most patients with oral thrush are asymptomatic. However, when symptomatic, patients typically experience a “sensation of cotton in their mouth,” along with a loss of taste. In some cases, pain during eating and swallowing occurs. Oropharyngeal examination typically reveals white plaques on the buccal mucosa, palate, tongue, or the oropharynx that is easily scrapable with an instrument like a tongue depressor. Confirmatory diagnosis can be made by scraping the lesions and performing KOH preparation on the scrapings, which will reveal budding yeasts with or without hyphae.   

Treatment for oral thrush involves antifungal therapy (e.g., clotrimazole, fluconazole) for several days. If no inciting event is known (e.g. prior antibiotic use), further investigation should be pursued, such as HIV testing.

Option Analysis

✅ Budding yeasts with and without hyphae:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hyperkeratosis overlying a thickened, acanthotic mucosal epithelium :
Incorrect: This answer describes leukoplakia – a benign (although precancerous) lesion of the tongue secondary to hyperplasia of the squamous mucosa. Leukoplakia may resemble thrush, appearing as white patches or plaques on the oral mucosa; however, unlike thrush, these lesions cannot be easily removed via scraping.
❌ Dysplasia with inflammation and vascular dilation:
Incorrect: Erythroplakia is a red, velvety lesion found on the oral mucosa and is associated with atypical epithelial changes, including an atrophic epithelium and prominent vasculature (giving this lesion its red, erythematous appearance). Erythroplakia is not easily scrapable with a tongue depressor.
❌ Septate hyphae with acute-angle branching:
Incorrect: These findings suggest an infection with the fungus Aspergillus. Invasive aspergillosis preferentially affects the lungs and manifests with necrotizing pneumonia. This patient has no clinical features to suggest a pulmonary or systemic infection, making this etiology unlikely. 
❌ Lymphocytic infiltrate along the dermo-epidermal junction:
Incorrect: This histologic description suggests lichen planus, which appears as a symmetrical white lace-like pattern on the buccal mucosa. It can be caused by certain drugs (antibiotics, NSAIDs), infections (hepatitis C), and cigarette smoking. This patient’s white, scrapable plaques are suggestive of a different condition.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to a sore throat and fever. The patient's symptoms started three days ago. Examination of the patient’s throat shows wide exudates on the tonsils, pharyngeal erythema, and cervical adenopathy.  A pharyngeal swab is performed and sent to the laboratory for Gram stain and culture, and bloodwork is drawn. The patient is started immediately on antibiotics.  Anti-streptolysin O antibody titers return several days later and are elevated. Which of the following characteristics of the most likely pathogen causing this patient’s condition?

choices.text: It causes alpha hemolysis on blood agar

questions.solution:
This patient likely has pharyngitis due to Streptococcus pyogenes (group A strep) because of the classic symptoms (fever, tonsillar exudate, cervical lymphadenopathy, lack of cough) and elevated anti-streptolysin O antibody titers. These antibody titers usually become positive/elevated several days to a week after the initial infection.

GAS is a Gram-positive catalase-negative coccus that clusters in chains and pairs. On blood agar, GAS causes beta-hemolysis, which is mainly mediated by the exotoxins of the bacteria (i.e., streptolysin O). GAS is encapsulated, which helps in preventing phagocytosis.

GAS that helps distinguish it from other beta-hemolytic streptococci (e.g. Streptococcus agalactiae) is pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR)-positive. GAS produces an enzyme called L-pyrrolidinyl arylamidase that converts pyrrolidonyl beta-naphthylamide to beta-naphthylamide. If pyrrolidonyl beta-naphthylamide were added to a culture of GAS, it would convert to beta-naphthylamide, which reacts with N-methylamino-cinnamaldehyde to produce a red color. The red color confirms that the bacteria is PYR-positive (i.e. produces this enzyme).  


Option Analysis

✅ It is pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR)-positive  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It is catalase-positive  :
Incorrect: Streptococcus pyogenes, like all other streptococci, is catalase negative.  
❌ It is a non-encapsulated bacterium:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pyogenes is an encapsulated bacterium.  
❌ It causes alpha hemolysis on blood agar:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pyogenes causes beta hemolysis on blood agar.  
❌ It produces a CAMP factor  :
Incorrect: Group B strep (Streptococcus agalactiae) produces CAMP, not group A strep (Streptococcus pyogenes).

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the clinic for an assessment of a tongue lesion. She states it is occasionally painful and has impacted her ability to eat. Her history is significant for active IV drug use and homelessness. She was recently hospitalized and treated for Pneumocystis pneumonia six months ago. She takes no medications and has not visited a primary care physician in over ten years. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a thin woman with temporal wasting and minimal muscle mass. Oral examination reveals a white lesion on the lateral margin of the tongue with “feathery” projections. The lesion is not easily scraped away with a tongue depressor. There are track marks and scars present in the bilateral antecubital fossa. The rest of the physical examination is noncontributory. The pathogen implicated in this patient’s tongue lesion is also associated with which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL) is an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)-mediated mucocutaneous condition involving the squamous epithelium of the tongue. Hairy leukoplakia is associated with HIV infection or immunosuppression – as suggested in this vignette by the patient’s history of IV drug use and recent hospitalization with PCP pneumonia. The pathophysiology of OHL depends on several factors, including EBV virulence/strain and host immune system factors.    

The lateral border of the tongue is more susceptible to mechanical trauma, predisposing epidermal cells at this location to infection with EBV. Hence, this condition is commonly discovered as a unilateral non-painful white lesion on the lateral margin of the tongue. The lesion may vary in appearance as either a smooth and flat or irregular, "hairy" or "feathery" lesion with prominent folds or projections. In contrast to oral thrush, OHL lesions are adherent to the surface and cannot be removed by scraping. The surrounding tissue does not typically demonstrate any signs of erythematous change. EBV is implicated in several conditions beyond OHL, such as infectious mononucleosis, Burkitt lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.  

Option Analysis

✅ Burkitt lymphoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Kaposi sarcoma:
Incorrect: Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8). Kaposi sarcoma presents with multiple cutaneous lesions (vascular tumors) and is almost exclusively seen in AIDS patients. A different pathogen precipitates this patient’s condition (hairy leukoplakia).
❌ Shingles:
Incorrect: Shingles is caused by reactivation of a prior infection with varicella-zoster virus (VZV) (i.e. chickenpox). A different pathogen causes this patient’s condition (hairy leukoplakia).
❌ Cervical cancer:
Incorrect: Cervical cancer is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). HPV preferentially infects squamous cells and can result in oropharyngeal cancers. However, this patient’s hairy leukoplakia is caused by a different virus. 
❌ Vulvovaginitis:
Incorrect: Vulvovaginitis occurs secondary to colonization with various pathogens, with one of the most common pathogens being Candida albicans. Oropharyngeal candidiasis, also known as oral thrush, is caused by C. albicans. A physical examination will reveal white plaques on the oral mucosa, similar to this patient. However, oral thrush is scrapable with a tongue depressor, unlike leukoplakia and erythroplakia (premalignant lesions).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic due to a painless jaw mass that started a few weeks ago. The mass has slowly increased in size and has recently begun producing a yellow discharge. The patient underwent molar extraction a few weeks prior to noticing the mass. Past medical history includes type 1 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.0 ºC (100.4 ºF), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows a painless mandibular mass with sinus tract formation and yellow purulent discharge. Gram stain and culture of the discharge shows Gram-positive bacteria with yellow sulfur granules. Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has actinomycosis, which is caused by Actinomyces israelii. A. israelii is a Gram-positive, filamentous bacterium that is part of the normal flora of the oral cavity, gastrointestinal tract, and genitourinary tract. When identified microscopically, it is often found in “sulfur granules,” which are just yellow-colored clumps of the filaments of Actinomyces (and do not necessarily contain sulfur).

A. israelli does not usually cause infections unless there is a breach to the mucosal barriers, allowing bacteria to invade deeper into tissues and cause infection. The inflammatory response is granulomatous and suppurative, and can eventually lead to abscess and/or sinus tract formation. Purulence is often characteristically yellow. Risk factors for actinomycosis include decreased immunity, such as in patients with HIV, leukemia, or poorly controlled diabetes mellitus.

The most common form of actinomycosis is maxillofacial actinomycosis, which usually results after dental caries or dental extraction. The patient usually presents with a painless mass in the jaw or face due to an abscess, with sinus tract formation and yellow discharge. If persistent, the infection may spread to the bones of the jaw and cause osteomyelitis. Diagnosis can be made with Gram-stain, as culture may take weeks. Treatment involves a prolonged course of antibiotics.  


Option Analysis

✅ Actinomyces israelii:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nocardia:
Incorrect: Nocardia does not usually cause maxillofacial infections and does not form yellow sulfur granules.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus can cause abscess formation in multiple tissues, but it does not cause the characteristic yellow sulfur granules.  
❌ Streptococcus pyogenes:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pyogenes can cause skin infections of the face, but it is unlikely to cause a maxillary/dental abscess and does not cause the characteristic yellow sulfur granules.  
❌ Serratia marcescens:
Incorrect: Serratia marcescens is a Gram-negative bacterium that is associated with red pigment production, not with maxillary abscesses or sulfur granule formation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the office with repeated episodes of epistaxis. He additionally notes recurrent headaches and trouble hearing in the right ear. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient endorses a 20 pack-year smoking history but does not use alcohol or illicit substances. He moved to the United States from China 10 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows several enlarged and non-tender cervical lymph nodes. Further evaluation of the nasopharynx reveals a mass in the pharyngeal recess. Cardiovascular and pulmonary examinations are noncontributory. Analysis of the mass cells will most likely reveal infection by which of the following viruses?
questions.solution:
This patient of Asian descent has epistaxis, headaches, and unilateral hearing loss in the setting of a pharyngeal mass and cervical lymphadenopathy. He most likely has nasopharyngeal carcinoma.  

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the most common cancer originating in the nasopharynx. It originates in the epithelial cells lining the nasopharynx in the fossa of Rosenmüller. Although rare in most parts of the world, it is endemic in Southern China, Southeast Asia, and North Africa. The major risk factors for nasopharyngeal carcinoma are Epstein Barr virus (HHV-4) infection, smoking, ingestion of salt-preserved foods, and genetic susceptibility.    

Individuals with the condition are initially asymptomatic. Cervical lymphadenopathy is the first sign in many patients. When the tumor grows larger, it can cause epistaxis, nasal obstruction, conductive hearing loss secondary to Eustachian tube obstruction, and the development of a middle ear effusion.  

The diagnosis is confirmed via indirect nasopharyngoscopy, CT or MRI of the head and neck, and endoscopic guided biopsy. Another clue is a positive heterophile antibody test, which confirms EBV infection. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma can be treated by surgery, chemotherapy, or radiotherapy.

Option Analysis

❌ HHV-2:
Incorrect: HHV-2, also known as herpes simplex virus-2, is involved in the pathogenesis of herpes genitalis. HHV-2 is typically not involved in nasal, oral, or pharyngeal disease.  
❌ HHV-3:
Incorrect: HHV-3, also known as varicella-zoster virus, is involved in the pathogenesis of chickenpox and shingles. This patient is presenting with epistaxis, headaches, hearing loss, and a pharyngeal mass. These symptoms are not consistent with the presentation of shingles or chickenpox.  
✅ HHV-4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ HHV-5:
Incorrect: HHV-5, also known as cytomegalovirus, is involved in the pathogenesis of infectious mononucleosis-like syndrome, congenital infections, transplant rejection, and infections in the immunocompromised (e.g., retinitis, pneumonia, gastroenteritis). However, it is not involved in the development of nasopharyngeal malignancies.  
❌ HHV-8:
Incorrect: HHV-8 is typically involved in the pathogenesis of Kaposi sarcoma, an endothelial malignancy associated with HIV. It is also associated with primary effusion lymphoma. However, HHV-8 is not typically involved in nasal, oral, and pharyngeal disease.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department to assess sudden-onset right facial pain. The patient is unable to open his mouth due to pain. He has been taking diphenhydramine multiple times a day for seasonal allergies. Medical history is significant for allergies and hypertension.
