Temperature is 38.6°C (101°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 125/83 mmHg. Physical examination reveals swelling, erythema, and tenderness over the right preauricular space. Laboratory studies demonstrate a leukocyte count of 16,200/mm<sup>3</sup>. Which of the following organisms is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute, unilateral facial pain, fever, and leukocytosis following recent sustained use of anticholinergics; he likely has acute suppurative parotitis.    

Acute bacterial suppurative parotitis occurs secondary to salivary stasis, which allows for retrograde seeding of the Stensen duct via mixed oral flora. Salivary stasis can be seen in patients who are dehydrated or have recently used anticholinergic drugs (e.g. diphenhydramine). Suppurative parotitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus but can also be caused by oral aerobes or anaerobes.  

Parotitis is characterized by the sudden onset of erythematous swelling of the preauricular areas that extend to the angle of the mandible. Patients also typically present with local pain and tenderness, often with trismus (e.g. reduced jaw opening) and dysphagia. Systemic findings of fever and chills may be present. Initial treatment of suppurative parotitis includes hydration and empiric antibiotics (e.g. nafcillin) directed against staphylococci and oral flora. 

Option Analysis

✅ Staphylococcal aureus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Haemophilus influenzae:
Incorrect: H. influenzae is a common cause of parotitis, but it is not the most commonly implicated organism. 
❌ Actinomyces:
Incorrect: Cervicofacial actinomycosis is a chronic disease characterized by abscess formation and draining sinus tracts. Dental infections and oromaxillofacial trauma are common preceding events. 
❌ Peptostreptococcus spp:
Incorrect: Oral anaerobes (e.g., Prevotella, Fusobacterium, Peptostreptococcus spp.) are less common causes of parotitis.
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: S. pneumoniae is a rare cause of parotitis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency room due to progressive difficulty breathing through the nose, excess nasal drainage, and difficulty smelling. Past medical history is notable for asthma, well-managed with an albuterol inhaler. The patient cannot think of any possible triggers but notes that the symptoms started soon after she sustained an ankle sprain two weeks ago. The injury has caused considerable pain, and she has been taking aspirin daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the lungs reveals occasional wheezing. Multiple polyps are noted in the bilateral nasal cavities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive breathing difficulties, excess drainage from the nose, and difficulty smelling. These symptoms started after she began taking aspirin for an ankle sprain. Given these factors, the patient most likely has an aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD).   

AERD arises since aspirin and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) work by inhibiting cyclooxygenase. This inhibition, in turn, shunts the arachidonic acid metabolic pathway towards leukotriene production. Increased leukotriene production leads to submucosal edema and breathing difficulties.  

Patients with AERD may present with nasal polyps, asthma, and aspirin sensitivity. This combination of symptoms is termed the Samter triad. In this patient's case, the history of nasal drainage and smelling difficulty are likely due to the nasal polyps.



Option Analysis

❌ Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:
Incorrect: Nasopharyngeal angiofibromas are benign but locally aggressive tumors of the nasal mucosa composed of large blood vessels and fibrous tissues. They often present with profuse epistaxis, unilateral complaints of nasal obstruction, and trouble breathing. They are most commonly seen in adolescent males. This patient’s presentation does not correlate with a nasopharynx angiofibroma. 
❌ Moderate asthma:
Incorrect: Moderate asthma can present with dyspnea, chest tightness, and persistent cough. Patients may also have increased respiratory rate, tachycardia, and wheezing audible throughout exhalation. Although this patient has been diagnosed with asthma, her presentation correlates more with symptom exacerbation due to a medication side-effect than disease progression. 
✅ Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chronic rhinitis:
Incorrect: Chronic rhinitis is characterized by long-term irritation and inflammation of the mucous membrane of the nasal cavity. Patients typically present with sneezing, runny nose, and postnasal drip. Bacteria, viruses, and allergens can trigger inflammation. However, this patient's symptoms developed after she began taking aspirin, which is more consistent with the presentation of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease. 
❌ Status asthmaticus:
Incorrect: Status asthmaticus describes a severe asthma exacerbation refractory to bronchodilator therapy. Patients present with severe dyspnea, accessory muscle use, and absence of lung sounds. In contrast, the patient in this vignette lacks such findings.
